guide.title: OS Level Tuning
guide.description: A guide to OS Level tuning for Sync Gateway.

introduction.paragraph: To get the most out of Sync Gateway, it may be necessary to tune a few parameters of the OS.

article.title: Tuning the max no. of file descriptors
article.description: This article walks you through raising the maximum number of file descriptors available to Sync Gateway.

introduction.paragraph: Raising the maximum number of file descriptors available to Sync Gateway is important because it directly affects the maximum number of sockets the Sync Gateway can have open, and therefore the maximum number of clients that the Sync Gateway can support.

article.title: Tuning the TCP Keepalive parameters
article.description: This article walks you through tuning the TCP Keepalive parameters.

introduction.paragraph: If you have already raised the maximum number of file descriptors available to Sync Gateway, but you are still seeing "too many open files" errors, you may need to tune the TCP Keepalive parameters.

body.paragraph: Mobile clients tend to abruptly disconnect from the network without closing their side of the connection, as desribed in Section 2.3. (Checking for dead peers) of the TCP-Keepalive-HOWTO.

By default, these connections will hang around for approximately 7200 seconds (2 hours) before they are detected to be dead and cleaned up by the tcp/ip stack of the Sync Gateway process. If enough of these connections accumulate, you can end up seeing "too many open files" errors on Sync Gateway.
If you are seeing "too many open files" errors, you can count the number of estabished connections coming into your sync gateway with the following command:

If the value returned is near your max file descriptor limit, then you can either try increasing the max file descriptor limit even higher, or tuning the TCP Keepalive parameters to reduce the amount of time that dead peers will cause a socket to be held open on their behalf.

Tuning the TCP Keepalive settings is not without its downsides -- it will increase the amount of overall network traffic on your system, because the tcp/ip stack will be sending more frequent Keepalive packets in order to detect dead peers faster.
